This growth was reflected in the non-oil manufacturing sector, which achieved a positive growth rate for the third consecutive quarter, reaching 17.74% during the second quarter of the 2024/2025 fiscal year, compared to the same period of the previous fiscal year, when the sector recorded a contraction rate of 11.56%. This growth was driven by the reform measures taken by the state to stimulate the national economy, foremost among them reforms aimed at increasing private sector participation in economic activity. In this regard, the government introduced customs clearance facilities for raw materials and inputs in the industrial sector, leading to increased industrial production. The sector’s contribution to GDP growth rose from 1.4- percentage points in the second quarter of the 2023/2024 fiscal year to 1.9 percentage points in this quarter, within an overall growth rate of 4.3%.Furthermore, this was also reflected in export volumes, as the state's exports of semi-manufactured and fully manufactured goods recorded significant growth during the second quarter of the 2024/2025 fiscal year. Semi-manufactured exports, which accounted for 22.4% of total merchandise exports, grew by 22.7% in the second quarter of 2024/2025 compared to the same quarter of the previous fiscal year. Fully manufactured exports, which contributed 52.1% of total merchandise exports, also grew by 8.3%. I didn’t grow up celebrating Eid – but living in Dubai has taught me just how special it really is. 🌙One of the things I’ve really come to appreciate since moving to Dubai is how the city embraces all cultures, and Eid is such a brilliant example of that.Whether you’re celebrating with family, friends, or just soaking in the atmosphere, there’s something special about this time of year. Streets lit up, gifts being exchanged, and a genuine feeling of togetherness that reminds you what matters most.As someone who didn’t grow up celebrating Eid, I’ve enjoyed learning more about it since living here. It’s not just about the public holidays or the incredible food (although that definitely helps 😄) it’s a time that brings people closer. A chance to reset, spend time with loved ones, and reflect on the year so far.For us as a family, it’s been another reminder of why we love living in Dubai. The way this city welcomes people from all walks of life and respects traditions from around the world is something quite unique.To all of you celebrating, Eid Mubarak! Wishing you and your loved ones peace, happiness and good health.And if you’re new to Dubai, I’d really recommend taking the time to experience how the city celebrates. It’s one of those cultural moments that makes living here feel all the more special.hashtag#EidMubarak hashtag#LifeInDubai hashtag#EidInDubai hashtag#ExpatsInDubai hashtag#Redbond hashtag#CulturalConnections hashtag#FamilyTime hashtag#LivingAbroad hashtag#WorkLifeBalance hashtag#DubaiCommunity

hashtag#Eid_holiday - Top Free Places to Visit in DubaiDubai offers plenty of incredible attractions that you can explore without spending a dirham on entry fees. Here are some of the best places to visit for free:1. Dubai Fountain Show (Downtown Dubai)Watch the world’s largest dancing fountain with synchronized music and lights. Timings: Every 30 minutes from 6 PM – 11 PM.2. Al Seef District (Dubai Creek)A scenic heritage area blending traditional souks with modern cafes and waterfront views.3. La Mer Beach (Jumeirah 1)A lively beachfront with stunning views, street art, and a relaxed atmosphere.4. JBR Walk & Beach (Dubai Marina)Enjoy a beautiful seaside promenade, street performances, and free beach access.5. Al Fahidi Historical District (Bur Dubai)Explore Dubai’s past through old wind-tower houses, museums, and art galleries.6. The Pointe, Palm JumeirahWaterfront views of Atlantis The Palm and the world’s largest fountain show.7. Ras Al Khor Wildlife SanctuaryA peaceful spot to watch flamingos and other migratory birds.8. Love Lake Dubai (Al Qudra)A heart-shaped lake surrounded by nature, ideal for a peaceful escape.9. Dubai Marina WalkA 7-km scenic walkway lined with skyscrapers, cafes, and nightlife spots.10. Key drivers include strategic infrastructure projects, hospitality investments, and a growing appetite for luxury, sustainable, and lifestyle-integrated properties.It's clear RAK's strategic vision is paying off, attracting significant investment and reshaping its economic landscape.

The Buej Al Arab ;The Burj Al Arab, standing at 321 meters (1,053 feet), is an iconic hotel in Dubai, designed to resemble a ship's sail. Its structural system includes a reinforced concrete core with a steel exoskeleton, allowing for its distinctive shape and open atrium, the tallest in the world at 180 meters. The building is supported by 250 foundation piles, each driven 45 meters into the sand to ensure stability on the artificial island it stands on. A diagonal bracing system counteracts wind and seismic forces, while its Teflon-coated fiberglass fabric façade reduces heat absorption. The Burj Al Arab remains a marvel of modern engineering and luxury architecture.

𝐖𝐡𝐞𝐫𝐞 𝐢𝐭 𝐚𝐥𝐥 𝐛𝐞𝐠𝐮𝐧, 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐯𝐢𝐬𝐢𝐨𝐧 𝐨𝐟 𝐭𝐨𝐝𝐚𝐲'𝐬 𝐃𝐮𝐛𝐚𝐢: The Saeed Al Maktoum House in Al Shindagha, Dubai, established around 1896 as the seat of the Al Maktoum family.🎯 In 1901 ruling Sheikh Maktoum bin Hasher Al Maktoum established Dubai as a free port with no taxation on imports or exports and also gave merchants parcels of land and guarantees of protection and tolerance. That was the cornerstone on which Dubai's rapid development built up. 🎯 His son Sheikh Saeed bin Maktoum bin Hasher Al Maktoum, ruling Dubai from 1912 to 1958, continued the open and welcoming economic policies of his father. 🎯 Later during his reign Sheikh Saeed bin Maktoum ceded many of the responsibilities for driving Dubai's economic growth to his son Rashid, who became ruler of Dubai in 1958, reigning until his death in 1990. 🎯 It was this son Sheikh Rashid bin Saeed Al Maktoum, also referred to as the Father of Modern Dubai, who concluded an agreement with British Imperial Airways for flights to take place through Dubai, with flights commencing in 1937. The agreement brought welcome revenue to Dubai and was the first step to establish Dubai as an international aviation hub. 👉 When you are in Dubai, take you time to visit the Saeed Al Maktoum House and the many additional exhibition venues in Al Shindagha to admire those Sheikhs' forward looking visions that you are benefiting from today. (Photo taken by me yesterday, 26/03/2025)hashtag#dubai hashtag#business hashtag#history hashtag#vision hashtag#shindagha

The UAE’s Economy: From Pearls to Artificial IntelligenceThe UAE was never a mere barren desert swept by the winds; rather, it was a cradle of dreams woven from the depths of the sea. Men once dived in search of pearls, those natural treasures that formed the backbone of the ancient economy. In those days, wooden boats sailed across the waters of the Gulf, carrying the hopes of sailors who braved the waves with unwavering hearts. Pearling was not merely a trade but a symbol of perseverance and patience—the very foundation of life that flourished along the shores.Then came oil, bringing with it a profound transformation in the economic landscape. The earth burst forth with its black treasures, and wealth flowed in torrents, reshaping the UAE from humble coastal settlements into dazzling oases of modernity. It was not merely a change of resources but a complete revolution in vision and planning. The wheels of development turned at an unprecedented pace, transforming sand dunes into skyscrapers and wooden dhows into world-class ports welcoming ships from every corner of the globe.Yet, the UAE did not rest on the laurels of oil wealth, for its leaders understood that finite riches could not sustain a lasting future. Thus began the leap toward a knowledge-based economy. Universities and research centers were established, technological initiatives were launched, and the UAE became a hub of innovation, attracting brilliant minds and ambitious startups. The economy was no longer just about trade and commodities but evolved into an intricate ecosystem of artificial intelligence, big data, and renewable energy, where human ingenuity intertwines seamlessly with technology.Today, the UAE stands on the threshold of the future—not only as a financial and commercial powerhouse but as a global laboratory for shaping the digital economy. From smart cities to space ventures, from artificial intelligence to blockchain technology, the UAE is redefining the contours of modern economic paradigms. This is a story written with the ink of boldness and vision, where the past was never a constraint but a launchpad toward horizons once thought unimaginable.

On March 21, 2025, the White House announced that the United Arab Emirates (UAE) committed to a 10-year, $1.4 trillion investment framework in the United States. This agreement followed a meeting between President Donald Trump and top UAE officials, including UAE National Security Adviser Sheikh Tahnoon bin Zayed Al Nahyan, earlier that week. The investment is intended to significantly expand the UAE's existing investments in the U.S. economy, focusing on areas such as AI infrastructure, semiconductors, energy, and manufacturing. One notable new project highlighted in the deal is an investment by Emirates Global Aluminium to build the first new aluminum smelter in the U.S. in 35 years, which is expected to nearly double domestic aluminum production.

Gulf Consulting Market: 2025 Update and Implications for R Consultancy GroupThe Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) consulting market has demonstrated robust growth, expanding by 13.2% in 2023 to reach $5.4 billion. This upward trajectory continued in 2024, with the market projected to hit approximately $8 billion by the end of 2025. Saudi Arabia remains a pivotal contributor, with its consulting sector growing by 14.1% in 2024 to $4.3 billion. ​Evolving Market DynamicsDespite this growth, the consulting landscape is experiencing shifts. Saudi Arabia is reassessing its expenditure on external consultants, leading to increased scrutiny and a demand for demonstrable value. This necessitates a focus on specialized expertise and tangible outcomes.​Strategic Opportunities for R Consultancy GroupThese developments present strategic opportunities for R Consultancy Group (RCG):​Specialized Expertise: RCG's deep understanding of the GCC market positions it to offer tailored solutions that address the region's unique challenges.​By focusing on delivering measurable results, RCG can meet the heightened expectations of clients seeking clear returns on their investments.​Staying abreast of market trends enables RCG to anticipate client needs and offer proactive solutions, reinforcing its role as a trusted advisor.​In summary, while the GCC consulting market continues to grow, firms must adapt to evolving client expectations. This growth was reflected in the non-oil manufacturing sector, which achieved a positive growth rate for the third consecutive quarter, reaching 17.74% during the second quarter of the 2024/2025 fiscal year, compared to the same period of the previous fiscal year, when the sector recorded a contraction rate of 11.56%. This growth was driven by the reform measures taken by the state to stimulate the national economy, foremost among them reforms aimed at increasing private sector participation in economic activity. In this regard, the government introduced customs clearance facilities for raw materials and inputs in the industrial sector, leading to increased industrial production. The sector’s contribution to GDP growth rose from 1.4- percentage points in the second quarter of the 2023/2024 fiscal year to 1.9 percentage points in this quarter, within an overall growth rate of 4.3%.Furthermore, this was also reflected in export volumes, as the state's exports of semi-manufactured and fully manufactured goods recorded significant growth during the second quarter of the 2024/2025 fiscal year. Semi-manufactured exports, which accounted for 22.4% of total merchandise exports, grew by 22.7% in the second quarter of 2024/2025 compared to the same quarter of the previous fiscal year. Fully manufactured exports, which contributed 52.1% of total merchandise exports, also grew by 8.3%. I didn’t grow up celebrating Eid – but living in Dubai has taught me just how special it really is. 🌙One of the things I’ve really come to appreciate since moving to Dubai is how the city embraces all cultures, and Eid is such a brilliant example of that.Whether you’re celebrating with family, friends, or just soaking in the atmosphere, there’s something special about this time of year. Streets lit up, gifts being exchanged, and a genuine feeling of togetherness that reminds you what matters most.As someone who didn’t grow up celebrating Eid, I’ve enjoyed learning more about it since living here. It’s not just about the public holidays or the incredible food (although that definitely helps 😄) it’s a time that brings people closer. A chance to reset, spend time with loved ones, and reflect on the year so far.For us as a family, it’s been another reminder of why we love living in Dubai. The way this city welcomes people from all walks of life and respects traditions from around the world is something quite unique.To all of you celebrating, Eid Mubarak! Wishing you and your loved ones peace, happiness and good health.And if you’re new to Dubai, I’d really recommend taking the time to experience how the city celebrates. It’s one of those cultural moments that makes living here feel all the more special.hashtag#EidMubarak hashtag#LifeInDubai hashtag#EidInDubai hashtag#ExpatsInDubai hashtag#Redbond hashtag#CulturalConnections hashtag#FamilyTime hashtag#LivingAbroad hashtag#WorkLifeBalance hashtag#DubaiCommunity

hashtag#Eid_holiday - Top Free Places to Visit in DubaiDubai offers plenty of incredible attractions that you can explore without spending a dirham on entry fees. Here are some of the best places to visit for free:1. Dubai Fountain Show (Downtown Dubai)Watch the world’s largest dancing fountain with synchronized music and lights. Timings: Every 30 minutes from 6 PM – 11 PM.2. Al Seef District (Dubai Creek)A scenic heritage area blending traditional souks with modern cafes and waterfront views.3. La Mer Beach (Jumeirah 1)A lively beachfront with stunning views, street art, and a relaxed atmosphere.4. JBR Walk & Beach (Dubai Marina)Enjoy a beautiful seaside promenade, street performances, and free beach access.5. The Pointe, Palm JumeirahWaterfront views of Atlantis The Palm and the world’s largest fountain show.7. Ras Al Khor Wildlife SanctuaryA peaceful spot to watch flamingos and other migratory birds.8. Love Lake Dubai (Al Qudra)A heart-shaped lake surrounded by nature, ideal for a peaceful escape.9. Dubai Marina WalkA 7-km scenic walkway lined with skyscrapers, cafes, and nightlife spots.10. City Walk (Downtown Dubai)A stylish urban district with free street art and futuristic architecture.14. Quranic Park (Al Khawaneej)A peaceful park with Quran-inspired gardens and exhibits.15. Located just a 90-minute drive from Dubai, this northern UAE emirate is rapidly gaining attention.🔹 Real estate transaction values leaped from AED 10M ($2.72M) in June 2017 to a massive AED 2.53 Billion ($688M) in June 2024. That's nearly a 25,000% increase!🔹 Mortgage values show a similar story, climbing from AED 15.8M in July 2017 to AED 3.47 Billion in July 2024 (~21,849% increase).According to Andrei Charapenak, CEO of Major Developers, this surge underscores soaring investor confidence and RAK's solidified position as a prime investment hub. Key drivers include strategic infrastructure projects, hospitality investments, and a growing appetite for luxury, sustainable, and lifestyle-integrated properties.It's clear RAK's strategic vision is paying off, attracting significant investment and reshaping its economic landscape.

The Buej Al Arab ;The Burj Al Arab, standing at 321 meters (1,053 feet), is an iconic hotel in Dubai, designed to resemble a ship's sail. Its structural system includes a reinforced concrete core with a steel exoskeleton, allowing for its distinctive shape and open atrium, the tallest in the world at 180 meters. The building is supported by 250 foundation piles, each driven 45 meters into the sand to ensure stability on the artificial island it stands on. A diagonal bracing system counteracts wind and seismic forces, while its Teflon-coated fiberglass fabric façade reduces heat absorption. The Burj Al Arab remains a marvel of modern engineering and luxury architecture.

𝐖𝐡𝐞𝐫𝐞 𝐢𝐭 𝐚𝐥𝐥 𝐛𝐞𝐠𝐮𝐧, 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐯𝐢𝐬𝐢𝐨𝐧 𝐨𝐟 𝐭𝐨𝐝𝐚𝐲'𝐬 𝐃𝐮𝐛𝐚𝐢: The Saeed Al Maktoum House in Al Shindagha, Dubai, established around 1896 as the seat of the Al Maktoum family.🎯 In 1901 ruling Sheikh Maktoum bin Hasher Al Maktoum established Dubai as a free port with no taxation on imports or exports and also gave merchants parcels of land and guarantees of protection and tolerance. That was the cornerstone on which Dubai's rapid development built up. 🎯 His son Sheikh Saeed bin Maktoum bin Hasher Al Maktoum, ruling Dubai from 1912 to 1958, continued the open and welcoming economic policies of his father. 🎯 Later during his reign Sheikh Saeed bin Maktoum ceded many of the responsibilities for driving Dubai's economic growth to his son Rashid, who became ruler of Dubai in 1958, reigning until his death in 1990. 🎯 It was this son Sheikh Rashid bin Saeed Al Maktoum, also referred to as the Father of Modern Dubai, who concluded an agreement with British Imperial Airways for flights to take place through Dubai, with flights commencing in 1937. The agreement brought welcome revenue to Dubai and was the first step to establish Dubai as an international aviation hub. 👉 When you are in Dubai, take you time to visit the Saeed Al Maktoum House and the many additional exhibition venues in Al Shindagha to admire those Sheikhs' forward looking visions that you are benefiting from today. (Photo taken by me yesterday, 26/03/2025)hashtag#dubai hashtag#business hashtag#history hashtag#vision hashtag#shindagha

Shaping the Future: Dubai's D33 VisionDubai's D33 Economic Agenda was launched on January 4, 2023 by His Highness Sheikh Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum, Vice President and Prime Minister of the UAE and Ruler of Dubai Dubai has always been synonymous with ambition, innovation, and a forward-thinking mindset. The UAE’s Economy: From Pearls to Artificial IntelligenceThe UAE was never a mere barren desert swept by the winds; rather, it was a cradle of dreams woven from the depths of the sea. Men once dived in search of pearls, those natural treasures that formed the backbone of the ancient economy. In those days, wooden boats sailed across the waters of the Gulf, carrying the hopes of sailors who braved the waves with unwavering hearts. Pearling was not merely a trade but a symbol of perseverance and patience—the very foundation of life that flourished along the shores.Then came oil, bringing with it a profound transformation in the economic landscape. The earth burst forth with its black treasures, and wealth flowed in torrents, reshaping the UAE from humble coastal settlements into dazzling oases of modernity. It was not merely a change of resources but a complete revolution in vision and planning. The wheels of development turned at an unprecedented pace, transforming sand dunes into skyscrapers and wooden dhows into world-class ports welcoming ships from every corner of the globe.Yet, the UAE did not rest on the laurels of oil wealth, for its leaders understood that finite riches could not sustain a lasting future. Thus began the leap toward a knowledge-based economy. Universities and research centers were established, technological initiatives were launched, and the UAE became a hub of innovation, attracting brilliant minds and ambitious startups. The economy was no longer just about trade and commodities but evolved into an intricate ecosystem of artificial intelligence, big data, and renewable energy, where human ingenuity intertwines seamlessly with technology.Today, the UAE stands on the threshold of the future—not only as a financial and commercial powerhouse but as a global laboratory for shaping the digital economy. From smart cities to space ventures, from artificial intelligence to blockchain technology, the UAE is redefining the contours of modern economic paradigms. This is a story written with the ink of boldness and vision, where the past was never a constraint but a launchpad toward horizons once thought unimaginable.

On March 21, 2025, the White House announced that the United Arab Emirates (UAE) committed to a 10-year, $1.4 trillion investment framework in the United States. This agreement followed a meeting between President Donald Trump and top UAE officials, including UAE National Security Adviser Sheikh Tahnoon bin Zayed Al Nahyan, earlier that week. The investment is intended to significantly expand the UAE's existing investments in the U.S. economy, focusing on areas such as AI infrastructure, semiconductors, energy, and manufacturing. One notable new project highlighted in the deal is an investment by Emirates Global Aluminium to build the first new aluminum smelter in the U.S. in 35 years, which is expected to nearly double domestic aluminum production.

Gulf Consulting Market: 2025 Update and Implications for R Consultancy GroupThe Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) consulting market has demonstrated robust growth, expanding by 13.2% in 2023 to reach $5.4 billion. This upward trajectory continued in 2024, with the market projected to hit approximately $8 billion by the end of 2025. Saudi Arabia remains a pivotal contributor, with its consulting sector growing by 14.1% in 2024 to $4.3 billion. ​Evolving Market DynamicsDespite this growth, the consulting landscape is experiencing shifts. This growth was reflected in the non-oil manufacturing sector, which achieved a positive growth rate for the third consecutive quarter, reaching 17.74% during the second quarter of the 2024/2025 fiscal year, compared to the same period of the previous fiscal year, when the sector recorded a contraction rate of 11.56%. This growth was driven by the reform measures taken by the state to stimulate the national economy, foremost among them reforms aimed at increasing private sector participation in economic activity. In this regard, the government introduced customs clearance facilities for raw materials and inputs in the industrial sector, leading to increased industrial production. The sector’s contribution to GDP growth rose from 1.4- percentage points in the second quarter of the 2023/2024 fiscal year to 1.9 percentage points in this quarter, within an overall growth rate of 4.3%.Furthermore, this was also reflected in export volumes, as the state's exports of semi-manufactured and fully manufactured goods recorded significant growth during the second quarter of the 2024/2025 fiscal year. Semi-manufactured exports, which accounted for 22.4% of total merchandise exports, grew by 22.7% in the second quarter of 2024/2025 compared to the same quarter of the previous fiscal year. Fully manufactured exports, which contributed 52.1% of total merchandise exports, also grew by 8.3%. I didn’t grow up celebrating Eid – but living in Dubai has taught me just how special it really is. 🌙One of the things I’ve really come to appreciate since moving to Dubai is how the city embraces all cultures, and Eid is such a brilliant example of that.Whether you’re celebrating with family, friends, or just soaking in the atmosphere, there’s something special about this time of year. Streets lit up, gifts being exchanged, and a genuine feeling of togetherness that reminds you what matters most.As someone who didn’t grow up celebrating Eid, I’ve enjoyed learning more about it since living here. It’s not just about the public holidays or the incredible food (although that definitely helps 😄) it’s a time that brings people closer. A chance to reset, spend time with loved ones, and reflect on the year so far.For us as a family, it’s been another reminder of why we love living in Dubai. The way this city welcomes people from all walks of life and respects traditions from around the world is something quite unique.To all of you celebrating, Eid Mubarak! Wishing you and your loved ones peace, happiness and good health.And if you’re new to Dubai, I’d really recommend taking the time to experience how the city celebrates. It’s one of those cultural moments that makes living here feel all the more special.hashtag#EidMubarak hashtag#LifeInDubai hashtag#EidInDubai hashtag#ExpatsInDubai hashtag#Redbond hashtag#CulturalConnections hashtag#FamilyTime hashtag#LivingAbroad hashtag#WorkLifeBalance hashtag#DubaiCommunity

**Investing in Mohammed Bin Rashid City Real Estate** 🌆✨Mohammed Bin Rashid City (MBR City) is one of the most exciting new developments in Dubai, offering both luxury living and incredible investment potential. Whether you're looking for a home or a rental property, MBR City offers endless possibilities.Looking to make an investment in this growing neighborhood? Here are some of the best places to visit for free:1. Dubai Fountain Show (Downtown Dubai)Watch the world’s largest dancing fountain with synchronized music and lights. Timings: Every 30 minutes from 6 PM – 11 PM.2. Al Seef District (Dubai Creek)A scenic heritage area blending traditional souks with modern cafes and waterfront views.3. La Mer Beach (Jumeirah 1)A lively beachfront with stunning views, street art, and a relaxed atmosphere.4. JBR Walk & Beach (Dubai Marina)Enjoy a beautiful seaside promenade, street performances, and free beach access.5. The Pointe, Palm JumeirahWaterfront views of Atlantis The Palm and the world’s largest fountain show.7. Ras Al Khor Wildlife SanctuaryA peaceful spot to watch flamingos and other migratory birds.8. Love Lake Dubai (Al Qudra)A heart-shaped lake surrounded by nature, ideal for a peaceful escape.9. Dubai Marina WalkA 7-km scenic walkway lined with skyscrapers, cafes, and nightlife spots.10. Bur Dubai Grand MosqueA beautiful mosque offering free cultural tours for non-Muslims.11. Hatta DamA stunning mountain landscape with crystal-clear waters, perfect for photography.12. Dubai Water Canal BoardwalkA picturesque walkway with a colorful waterfall bridge and skyline views.13. City Walk (Downtown Dubai)A stylish urban district with free street art and futuristic architecture.14. Quranic Park (Al Khawaneej)A peaceful park with Quran-inspired gardens and exhibits.15. Kite Beach (Jumeirah)A public beach great for swimming, jogging, and watching kitesurfers.16. Gold & Spice Souks (Deira)Explore traditional markets with dazzling jewelry and aromatic spices.17. The Buej Al Arab ;The Burj Al Arab, standing at 321 meters (1,053 feet), is an iconic hotel in Dubai, designed to resemble a ship's sail. Its structural system includes a reinforced concrete core with a steel exoskeleton, allowing for its distinctive shape and open atrium, the tallest in the world at 180 meters. The building is supported by 250 foundation piles, each driven 45 meters into the sand to ensure stability on the artificial island it stands on. A diagonal bracing system counteracts wind and seismic forces, while its Teflon-coated fiberglass fabric façade reduces heat absorption. The Burj Al Arab remains a marvel of modern engineering and luxury architecture.

𝐖𝐡𝐞𝐫𝐞 𝐢𝐭 𝐚𝐥𝐥 𝐛𝐞𝐠𝐮𝐧, 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐯𝐢𝐬𝐢𝐨𝐧 𝐨𝐟 𝐭𝐨𝐝𝐚𝐲'𝐬 𝐃𝐮𝐛𝐚𝐢: The Saeed Al Maktoum House in Al Shindagha, Dubai, established around 1896 as the seat of the Al Maktoum family.🎯 In 1901 ruling Sheikh Maktoum bin Hasher Al Maktoum established Dubai as a free port with no taxation on imports or exports and also gave merchants parcels of land and guarantees of protection and tolerance. That was the cornerstone on which Dubai's rapid development built up. 🎯 His son Sheikh Saeed bin Maktoum bin Hasher Al Maktoum, ruling Dubai from 1912 to 1958, continued the open and welcoming economic policies of his father. 🎯 Later during his reign Sheikh Saeed bin Maktoum ceded many of the responsibilities for driving Dubai's economic growth to his son Rashid, who became ruler of Dubai in 1958, reigning until his death in 1990. 🎯 It was this son Sheikh Rashid bin Saeed Al Maktoum, also referred to as the Father of Modern Dubai, who concluded an agreement with British Imperial Airways for flights to take place through Dubai, with flights commencing in 1937. The agreement brought welcome revenue to Dubai and was the first step to establish Dubai as an international aviation hub. 👉 When you are in Dubai, take you time to visit the Saeed Al Maktoum House and the many additional exhibition venues in Al Shindagha to admire those Sheikhs' forward looking visions that you are benefiting from today. (Photo taken by me yesterday, 26/03/2025)hashtag#dubai hashtag#business hashtag#history hashtag#vision hashtag#shindagha

The UAE’s Economy: From Pearls to Artificial IntelligenceThe UAE was never a mere barren desert swept by the winds; rather, it was a cradle of dreams woven from the depths of the sea. Men once dived in search of pearls, those natural treasures that formed the backbone of the ancient economy. In those days, wooden boats sailed across the waters of the Gulf, carrying the hopes of sailors who braved the waves with unwavering hearts. Pearling was not merely a trade but a symbol of perseverance and patience—the very foundation of life that flourished along the shores.Then came oil, bringing with it a profound transformation in the economic landscape. The earth burst forth with its black treasures, and wealth flowed in torrents, reshaping the UAE from humble coastal settlements into dazzling oases of modernity. It was not merely a change of resources but a complete revolution in vision and planning. The wheels of development turned at an unprecedented pace, transforming sand dunes into skyscrapers and wooden dhows into world-class ports welcoming ships from every corner of the globe.Yet, the UAE did not rest on the laurels of oil wealth, for its leaders understood that finite riches could not sustain a lasting future. Thus began the leap toward a knowledge-based economy. Universities and research centers were established, technological initiatives were launched, and the UAE became a hub of innovation, attracting brilliant minds and ambitious startups. The economy was no longer just about trade and commodities but evolved into an intricate ecosystem of artificial intelligence, big data, and renewable energy, where human ingenuity intertwines seamlessly with technology.Today, the UAE stands on the threshold of the future—not only as a financial and commercial powerhouse but as a global laboratory for shaping the digital economy. From smart cities to space ventures, from artificial intelligence to blockchain technology, the UAE is redefining the contours of modern economic paradigms. This is a story written with the ink of boldness and vision, where the past was never a constraint but a launchpad toward horizons once thought unimaginable.

On March 21, 2025, the White House announced that the United Arab Emirates (UAE) committed to a 10-year, $1.4 trillion investment framework in the United States. This agreement followed a meeting between President Donald Trump and top UAE officials, including UAE National Security Adviser Sheikh Tahnoon bin Zayed Al Nahyan, earlier that week. The investment is intended to significantly expand the UAE's existing investments in the U.S. economy, focusing on areas such as AI infrastructure, semiconductors, energy, and manufacturing. One notable new project highlighted in the deal is an investment by Emirates Global Aluminium to build the first new aluminum smelter in the U.S. in 35 years, which is expected to nearly double domestic aluminum production.

This growth was reflected in the non-oil manufacturing sector, which achieved a positive growth rate for the third consecutive quarter, reaching 17.74% during the second quarter of the 2024/2025 fiscal year, compared to the same period of the previous fiscal year, when the sector recorded a contraction rate of 11.56%. This growth was driven by the reform measures taken by the state to stimulate the national economy, foremost among them reforms aimed at increasing private sector participation in economic activity. In this regard, the government introduced customs clearance facilities for raw materials and inputs in the industrial sector, leading to increased industrial production. The sector’s contribution to GDP growth rose from 1.4- percentage points in the second quarter of the 2023/2024 fiscal year to 1.9 percentage points in this quarter, within an overall growth rate of 4.3%.Furthermore, this was also reflected in export volumes, as the state's exports of semi-manufactured and fully manufactured goods recorded significant growth during the second quarter of the 2024/2025 fiscal year. Semi-manufactured exports, which accounted for 22.4% of total merchandise exports, grew by 22.7% in the second quarter of 2024/2025 compared to the same quarter of the previous fiscal year. Fully manufactured exports, which contributed 52.1% of total merchandise exports, also grew by 8.3%. I didn’t grow up celebrating Eid – but living in Dubai has taught me just how special it really is. 🌙One of the things I’ve really come to appreciate since moving to Dubai is how the city embraces all cultures, and Eid is such a brilliant example of that.Whether you’re celebrating with family, friends, or just soaking in the atmosphere, there’s something special about this time of year. Streets lit up, gifts being exchanged, and a genuine feeling of togetherness that reminds you what matters most.As someone who didn’t grow up celebrating Eid, I’ve enjoyed learning more about it since living here. It’s not just about the public holidays or the incredible food (although that definitely helps 😄) it’s a time that brings people closer. A chance to reset, spend time with loved ones, and reflect on the year so far.For us as a family, it’s been another reminder of why we love living in Dubai. The way this city welcomes people from all walks of life and respects traditions from around the world is something quite unique.To all of you celebrating, Eid Mubarak! Wishing you and your loved ones peace, happiness and good health.And if you’re new to Dubai, I’d really recommend taking the time to experience how the city celebrates. hashtag#Eid_holiday - Top Free Places to Visit in DubaiDubai offers plenty of incredible attractions that you can explore without spending a dirham on entry fees. Here are some of the best places to visit for free:1. Dubai Fountain Show (Downtown Dubai)Watch the world’s largest dancing fountain with synchronized music and lights. Timings: Every 30 minutes from 6 PM – 11 PM.2. Al Seef District (Dubai Creek)A scenic heritage area blending traditional souks with modern cafes and waterfront views.3. La Mer Beach (Jumeirah 1)A lively beachfront with stunning views, street art, and a relaxed atmosphere.4. JBR Walk & Beach (Dubai Marina)Enjoy a beautiful seaside promenade, street performances, and free beach access.5. Al Fahidi Historical District (Bur Dubai)Explore Dubai’s past through old wind-tower houses, museums, and art galleries.6. The Pointe, Palm JumeirahWaterfront views of Atlantis The Palm and the world’s largest fountain show.7. Ras Al Khor Wildlife SanctuaryA peaceful spot to watch flamingos and other migratory birds.8. Love Lake Dubai (Al Qudra)A heart-shaped lake surrounded by nature, ideal for a peaceful escape.9. Dubai Marina WalkA 7-km scenic walkway lined with skyscrapers, cafes, and nightlife spots.10. Bur Dubai Grand MosqueA beautiful mosque offering free cultural tours for non-Muslims.11. Hatta DamA stunning mountain landscape with crystal-clear waters, perfect for photography.12. Dubai Water Canal BoardwalkA picturesque walkway with a colorful waterfall bridge and skyline views.13. City Walk (Downtown Dubai)A stylish urban district with free street art and futuristic architecture.14. Quranic Park (Al Khawaneej)A peaceful park with Quran-inspired gardens and exhibits.15. Kite Beach (Jumeirah)A public beach great for swimming, jogging, and watching kitesurfers.16. Gold & Spice Souks (Deira)Explore traditional markets with dazzling jewelry and aromatic spices.17. Dubai Mall & Aquarium (Outside View)Enjoy free views of the massive Dubai Aquarium inside The Dubai Mall.Dubai has plenty of amazing free experiences—which one will you visit first?hashtag#Eid hashtag#holidays hashtag#Dubai hashtag#free hashtag#dubaimall hashtag#burjkhalifa hashtag#goldsouk hashtag#aquarium hashtag#Kitebeach hashtag#citywalk hashtag#Hatta hashtag#watercanal hashtag#Marina hashtag#lovelake hashtag#JBR hashtag#La_mer hashtag#beach hashtag#Dubaifountainshow

Located just a 90-minute drive from Dubai, this northern UAE emirate is rapidly gaining attention.🔹 Real estate transaction values leaped from AED 10M ($2.72M) in June 2017 to a massive AED 2.53 Billion ($688M) in June 2024. Key drivers include strategic infrastructure projects, hospitality investments, and a growing appetite for luxury, sustainable, and lifestyle-integrated properties.It's clear RAK's strategic vision is paying off, attracting significant investment and reshaping its economic landscape.

Post Content:
The Buej Al Arab ;The Burj Al Arab, standing at 321 meters (1,053 feet), is an iconic hotel in Dubai, designed to resemble a ship's sail. Its structural system includes a reinforced concrete core with a steel exoskeleton, allowing for its distinctive shape and open atrium, the tallest in the world at 180 meters. The building is supported by 250 foundation piles, each driven 45 meters into the sand to ensure stability on the artificial island it stands on. A diagonal bracing system counteracts wind and seismic forces, while its Teflon-coated fiberglass fabric façade reduces heat absorption. The Burj Al Arab remains a marvel of modern engineering and luxury architecture.

𝐖𝐡𝐞𝐫𝐞 𝐢𝐭 𝐚𝐥𝐥 𝐛𝐞𝐠𝐮𝐧, 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐯𝐢𝐬𝐢𝐨𝐧 𝐨𝐟 𝐭𝐨𝐝𝐚𝐲'𝐬 𝐃𝐮𝐛𝐚𝐢: The Saeed Al Maktoum House in Al Shindagha, Dubai, established around 1896 as the seat of the Al Maktoum family.🎯 In 1901 ruling Sheikh Maktoum bin Hasher Al Maktoum established Dubai as a free port with no taxation on imports or exports and also gave merchants parcels of land and guarantees of protection and tolerance. That was the cornerstone on which Dubai's rapid development built up. 🎯 His son Sheikh Saeed bin Maktoum bin Hasher Al Maktoum, ruling Dubai from 1912 to 1958, continued the open and welcoming economic policies of his father. 🎯 Later during his reign Sheikh Saeed bin Maktoum ceded many of the responsibilities for driving Dubai's economic growth to his son Rashid, who became ruler of Dubai in 1958, reigning until his death in 1990. 🎯 It was this son Sheikh Rashid bin Saeed Al Maktoum, also referred to as the Father of Modern Dubai, who concluded an agreement with British Imperial Airways for flights to take place through Dubai, with flights commencing in 1937. The agreement brought welcome revenue to Dubai and was the first step to establish Dubai as an international aviation hub. 👉 When you are in Dubai, take you time to visit the Saeed Al Maktoum House and the many additional exhibition venues in Al Shindagha to admire those Sheikhs' forward looking visions that you are benefiting from today. With the D33 vision, the emirate reinforces its reputation as a beacon of opportunity for businesses and investors worldwide.

I took my father-in-law who has traveled around the World but was still very much amazed to visit DUBAI SPICE SOUKThe Dubai Spice Souk is a bustling marketplace in the Deira district, renowned for its rich aromas and vibrant displays of spices, herbs, and dried goods. It’s not just a feast for the senses but a hub of economic activity, offering opportunities for businesses in the culinary, hospitality, and retail sectors. Entrepreneurs often source unique and high-quality ingredients, such as saffron, cinnamon, and traditional incense, to enhance their product offerings. The Souk’s approachable vendors are skilled at negotiation, making it an excellent environment for bulk purchases and cultivating supplier relationships.For business owners, the Spice Souk is more than a shopping destination—it’s a chance to tap into the heritage and authenticity that can elevate branding and customer experience.His comment- Dubai has everything to offer from luxury, brands & a perfect mix of traditional as well as modern day’s requirements. The UAE’s Economy: From Pearls to Artificial IntelligenceThe UAE was never a mere barren desert swept by the winds; rather, it was a cradle of dreams woven from the depths of the sea. Men once dived in search of pearls, those natural treasures that formed the backbone of the ancient economy. In those days, wooden boats sailed across the waters of the Gulf, carrying the hopes of sailors who braved the waves with unwavering hearts. Pearling was not merely a trade but a symbol of perseverance and patience—the very foundation of life that flourished along the shores.Then came oil, bringing with it a profound transformation in the economic landscape. The earth burst forth with its black treasures, and wealth flowed in torrents, reshaping the UAE from humble coastal settlements into dazzling oases of modernity. It was not merely a change of resources but a complete revolution in vision and planning. The wheels of development turned at an unprecedented pace, transforming sand dunes into skyscrapers and wooden dhows into world-class ports welcoming ships from every corner of the globe.Yet, the UAE did not rest on the laurels of oil wealth, for its leaders understood that finite riches could not sustain a lasting future. Thus began the leap toward a knowledge-based economy. Universities and research centers were established, technological initiatives were launched, and the UAE became a hub of innovation, attracting brilliant minds and ambitious startups. The economy was no longer just about trade and commodities but evolved into an intricate ecosystem of artificial intelligence, big data, and renewable energy, where human ingenuity intertwines seamlessly with technology.Today, the UAE stands on the threshold of the future—not only as a financial and commercial powerhouse but as a global laboratory for shaping the digital economy. From smart cities to space ventures, from artificial intelligence to blockchain technology, the UAE is redefining the contours of modern economic paradigms. This is a story written with the ink of boldness and vision, where the past was never a constraint but a launchpad toward horizons once thought unimaginable.

On March 21, 2025, the White House announced that the United Arab Emirates (UAE) committed to a 10-year, $1.4 trillion investment framework in the United States. This agreement followed a meeting between President Donald Trump and top UAE officials, including UAE National Security Adviser Sheikh Tahnoon bin Zayed Al Nahyan, earlier that week. The investment is intended to significantly expand the UAE's existing investments in the U.S. economy, focusing on areas such as AI infrastructure, semiconductors, energy, and manufacturing. One notable new project highlighted in the deal is an investment by Emirates Global Aluminium to build the first new aluminum smelter in the U.S. in 35 years, which is expected to nearly double domestic aluminum production.

This growth was reflected in the non-oil manufacturing sector, which achieved a positive growth rate for the third consecutive quarter, reaching 17.74% during the second quarter of the 2024/2025 fiscal year, compared to the same period of the previous fiscal year, when the sector recorded a contraction rate of 11.56%. This growth was driven by the reform measures taken by the state to stimulate the national economy, foremost among them reforms aimed at increasing private sector participation in economic activity. In this regard, the government introduced customs clearance facilities for raw materials and inputs in the industrial sector, leading to increased industrial production. The sector’s contribution to GDP growth rose from 1.4- percentage points in the second quarter of the 2023/2024 fiscal year to 1.9 percentage points in this quarter, within an overall growth rate of 4.3%.Furthermore, this was also reflected in export volumes, as the state's exports of semi-manufactured and fully manufactured goods recorded significant growth during the second quarter of the 2024/2025 fiscal year. Semi-manufactured exports, which accounted for 22.4% of total merchandise exports, grew by 22.7% in the second quarter of 2024/2025 compared to the same quarter of the previous fiscal year. Fully manufactured exports, which contributed 52.1% of total merchandise exports, also grew by 8.3%. I didn’t grow up celebrating Eid – but living in Dubai has taught me just how special it really is. 🌙One of the things I’ve really come to appreciate since moving to Dubai is how the city embraces all cultures, and Eid is such a brilliant example of that.Whether you’re celebrating with family, friends, or just soaking in the atmosphere, there’s something special about this time of year. It’s not just about the public holidays or the incredible food (although that definitely helps 😄) it’s a time that brings people closer. A chance to reset, spend time with loved ones, and reflect on the year so far.For us as a family, it’s been another reminder of why we love living in Dubai. The way this city welcomes people from all walks of life and respects traditions from around the world is something quite unique.To all of you celebrating, Eid Mubarak! Wishing you and your loved ones peace, happiness and good health.And if you’re new to Dubai, I’d really recommend taking the time to experience how the city celebrates. hashtag#Eid_holiday - Top Free Places to Visit in DubaiDubai offers plenty of incredible attractions that you can explore without spending a dirham on entry fees. Here are some of the best places to visit for free:1. Dubai Fountain Show (Downtown Dubai)Watch the world’s largest dancing fountain with synchronized music and lights. Timings: Every 30 minutes from 6 PM – 11 PM.2. Al Seef District (Dubai Creek)A scenic heritage area blending traditional souks with modern cafes and waterfront views.3. La Mer Beach (Jumeirah 1)A lively beachfront with stunning views, street art, and a relaxed atmosphere.4. JBR Walk & Beach (Dubai Marina)Enjoy a beautiful seaside promenade, street performances, and free beach access.5. Al Fahidi Historical District (Bur Dubai)Explore Dubai’s past through old wind-tower houses, museums, and art galleries.6. The Pointe, Palm JumeirahWaterfront views of Atlantis The Palm and the world’s largest fountain show.7. Ras Al Khor Wildlife SanctuaryA peaceful spot to watch flamingos and other migratory birds.8. Love Lake Dubai (Al Qudra)A heart-shaped lake surrounded by nature, ideal for a peaceful escape.9. Dubai Marina WalkA 7-km scenic walkway lined with skyscrapers, cafes, and nightlife spots.10. Bur Dubai Grand MosqueA beautiful mosque offering free cultural tours for non-Muslims.11. Hatta DamA stunning mountain landscape with crystal-clear waters, perfect for photography.12. Dubai Water Canal BoardwalkA picturesque walkway with a colorful waterfall bridge and skyline views.13. City Walk (Downtown Dubai)A stylish urban district with free street art and futuristic architecture.14. Quranic Park (Al Khawaneej)A peaceful park with Quran-inspired gardens and exhibits.15. Kite Beach (Jumeirah)A public beach great for swimming, jogging, and watching kitesurfers.16. Gold & Spice Souks (Deira)Explore traditional markets with dazzling jewelry and aromatic spices.17. Dubai Mall & Aquarium (Outside View)Enjoy free views of the massive Dubai Aquarium inside The Dubai Mall.Dubai has plenty of amazing free experiences—which one will you visit first?hashtag#Eid hashtag#holidays hashtag#Dubai hashtag#free hashtag#dubaimall hashtag#burjkhalifa hashtag#goldsouk hashtag#aquarium hashtag#Kitebeach hashtag#citywalk hashtag#Hatta hashtag#watercanal hashtag#Marina hashtag#lovelake hashtag#JBR hashtag#La_mer hashtag#beach hashtag#Dubaifountainshow

The Buej Al Arab ;The Burj Al Arab, standing at 321 meters (1,053 feet), is an iconic hotel in Dubai, designed to resemble a ship's sail. Its structural system includes a reinforced concrete core with a steel exoskeleton, allowing for its distinctive shape and open atrium, the tallest in the world at 180 meters. The building is supported by 250 foundation piles, each driven 45 meters into the sand to ensure stability on the artificial island it stands on. A diagonal bracing system counteracts wind and seismic forces, while its Teflon-coated fiberglass fabric façade reduces heat absorption. The Burj Al Arab remains a marvel of modern engineering and luxury architecture.

𝐖𝐡𝐞𝐫𝐞 𝐢𝐭 𝐚𝐥𝐥 𝐛𝐞𝐠𝐮𝐧, 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐯𝐢𝐬𝐢𝐨𝐧 𝐨𝐟 𝐭𝐨𝐝𝐚𝐲'𝐬 𝐃𝐮𝐛𝐚𝐢: The Saeed Al Maktoum House in Al Shindagha, Dubai, established around 1896 as the seat of the Al Maktoum family.🎯 In 1901 ruling Sheikh Maktoum bin Hasher Al Maktoum established Dubai as a free port with no taxation on imports or exports and also gave merchants parcels of land and guarantees of protection and tolerance. That was the cornerstone on which Dubai's rapid development built up. 🎯 His son Sheikh Saeed bin Maktoum bin Hasher Al Maktoum, ruling Dubai from 1912 to 1958, continued the open and welcoming economic policies of his father. 🎯 Later during his reign Sheikh Saeed bin Maktoum ceded many of the responsibilities for driving Dubai's economic growth to his son Rashid, who became ruler of Dubai in 1958, reigning until his death in 1990. 🎯 It was this son Sheikh Rashid bin Saeed Al Maktoum, also referred to as the Father of Modern Dubai, who concluded an agreement with British Imperial Airways for flights to take place through Dubai, with flights commencing in 1937. The agreement brought welcome revenue to Dubai and was the first step to establish Dubai as an international aviation hub. 👉 When you are in Dubai, take you time to visit the Saeed Al Maktoum House and the many additional exhibition venues in Al Shindagha to admire those Sheikhs' forward looking visions that you are benefiting from today. (Photo taken by me yesterday, 26/03/2025)hashtag#dubai hashtag#business hashtag#history hashtag#vision hashtag#shindagha

Shaping the Future: Dubai's D33 VisionDubai's D33 Economic Agenda was launched on January 4, 2023 by His Highness Sheikh Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum, Vice President and Prime Minister of the UAE and Ruler of Dubai Dubai has always been synonymous with ambition, innovation, and a forward-thinking mindset. In line with this spirit, the Dubai Economic Agenda (D33) is a transformative blueprint designed to propel the emirate into an era of unparalleled economic growth and global influence.For businesses, the opportunities are abundant. The agenda opens doors to:Entrepreneurship: With initiatives to nurture startups and small businesses, entrepreneurs can thrive in an ecosystem built on innovation and support.Global Market Access: Dubai's strategic location, combined with its focus on trade and logistics, makes it a gateway for companies looking to expand their global reach.Sustainability Initiatives: Investment in renewable energy and green technologies creates avenues for businesses contributing to a sustainable future.Diverse Sectors: From technology and real estate to tourism and finance, D33 caters to diverse industries, ensuring a broad range of opportunities.For legal professionals, such as myself, D33's ambitious agenda also highlights the importance of navigating regulatory frameworks and fostering collaborations that ensure mutual growth and compliance in this dynamic business environment.Dubai is not just planning for the future, it's building it today. With the D33 vision, the emirate reinforces its reputation as a beacon of opportunity for businesses and investors worldwide.

I took my father-in-law who has traveled around the World but was still very much amazed to visit DUBAI SPICE SOUKThe Dubai Spice Souk is a bustling marketplace in the Deira district, renowned for its rich aromas and vibrant displays of spices, herbs, and dried goods. It’s not just a feast for the senses but a hub of economic activity, offering opportunities for businesses in the culinary, hospitality, and retail sectors. Entrepreneurs often source unique and high-quality ingredients, such as saffron, cinnamon, and traditional incense, to enhance their product offerings. The Souk’s approachable vendors are skilled at negotiation, making it an excellent environment for bulk purchases and cultivating supplier relationships.For business owners, the Spice Souk is more than a shopping destination—it’s a chance to tap into the heritage and authenticity that can elevate branding and customer experience.His comment- Dubai has everything to offer from luxury, brands & a perfect mix of traditional as well as modern day’s requirements. The UAE’s Economy: From Pearls to Artificial IntelligenceThe UAE was never a mere barren desert swept by the winds; rather, it was a cradle of dreams woven from the depths of the sea. Men once dived in search of pearls, those natural treasures that formed the backbone of the ancient economy. In those days, wooden boats sailed across the waters of the Gulf, carrying the hopes of sailors who braved the waves with unwavering hearts. Pearling was not merely a trade but a symbol of perseverance and patience—the very foundation of life that flourished along the shores.Then came oil, bringing with it a profound transformation in the economic landscape. The earth burst forth with its black treasures, and wealth flowed in torrents, reshaping the UAE from humble coastal settlements into dazzling oases of modernity. It was not merely a change of resources but a complete revolution in vision and planning. The wheels of development turned at an unprecedented pace, transforming sand dunes into skyscrapers and wooden dhows into world-class ports welcoming ships from every corner of the globe.Yet, the UAE did not rest on the laurels of oil wealth, for its leaders understood that finite riches could not sustain a lasting future. Thus began the leap toward a knowledge-based economy. Universities and research centers were established, technological initiatives were launched, and the UAE became a hub of innovation, attracting brilliant minds and ambitious startups. The economy was no longer just about trade and commodities but evolved into an intricate ecosystem of artificial intelligence, big data, and renewable energy, where human ingenuity intertwines seamlessly with technology.Today, the UAE stands on the threshold of the future—not only as a financial and commercial powerhouse but as a global laboratory for shaping the digital economy. From smart cities to space ventures, from artificial intelligence to blockchain technology, the UAE is redefining the contours of modern economic paradigms. This is a story written with the ink of boldness and vision, where the past was never a constraint but a launchpad toward horizons once thought unimaginable.

On March 21, 2025, the White House announced that the United Arab Emirates (UAE) committed to a 10-year, $1.4 trillion investment framework in the United States. This agreement followed a meeting between President Donald Trump and top UAE officials, including UAE National Security Adviser Sheikh Tahnoon bin Zayed Al Nahyan, earlier that week. The investment is intended to significantly expand the UAE's existing investments in the U.S. economy, focusing on areas such as AI infrastructure, semiconductors, energy, and manufacturing. One notable new project highlighted in the deal is an investment by Emirates Global Aluminium to build the first new aluminum smelter in the U.S. in 35 years, which is expected to nearly double domestic aluminum production.

This upward trajectory continued in 2024, with the market projected to hit approximately $8 billion by the end of 2025. Saudi Arabia remains a pivotal contributor, with its consulting sector growing by 14.1% in 2024 to $4.3 billion. ​Evolving Market DynamicsDespite this growth, the consulting landscape is experiencing shifts. Saudi Arabia is reassessing its expenditure on external consultants, leading to increased scrutiny and a demand for demonstrable value. This growth was reflected in the non-oil manufacturing sector, which achieved a positive growth rate for the third consecutive quarter, reaching 17.74% during the second quarter of the 2024/2025 fiscal year, compared to the same period of the previous fiscal year, when the sector recorded a contraction rate of 11.56%. This growth was driven by the reform measures taken by the state to stimulate the national economy, foremost among them reforms aimed at increasing private sector participation in economic activity. In this regard, the government introduced customs clearance facilities for raw materials and inputs in the industrial sector, leading to increased industrial production. The sector’s contribution to GDP growth rose from 1.4- percentage points in the second quarter of the 2023/2024 fiscal year to 1.9 percentage points in this quarter, within an overall growth rate of 4.3%.Furthermore, this was also reflected in export volumes, as the state's exports of semi-manufactured and fully manufactured goods recorded significant growth during the second quarter of the 2024/2025 fiscal year. Semi-manufactured exports, which accounted for 22.4% of total merchandise exports, grew by 22.7% in the second quarter of 2024/2025 compared to the same quarter of the previous fiscal year. Fully manufactured exports, which contributed 52.1% of total merchandise exports, also grew by 8.3%. I didn’t grow up celebrating Eid – but living in Dubai has taught me just how special it really is. 🌙One of the things I’ve really come to appreciate since moving to Dubai is how the city embraces all cultures, and Eid is such a brilliant example of that.Whether you’re celebrating with family, friends, or just soaking in the atmosphere, there’s something special about this time of year. Streets lit up, gifts being exchanged, and a genuine feeling of togetherness that reminds you what matters most.As someone who didn’t grow up celebrating Eid, I’ve enjoyed learning more about it since living here. It’s not just about the public holidays or the incredible food (although that definitely helps 😄) it’s a time that brings people closer. A chance to reset, spend time with loved ones, and reflect on the year so far.For us as a family, it’s been another reminder of why we love living in Dubai. The way this city welcomes people from all walks of life and respects traditions from around the world is something quite unique.To all of you celebrating, Eid Mubarak! Wishing you and your loved ones peace, happiness and good health.And if you’re new to Dubai, I’d really recommend taking the time to experience how the city celebrates. It’s one of those cultural moments that makes living here feel all the more special.hashtag#EidMubarak hashtag#LifeInDubai hashtag#EidInDubai hashtag#ExpatsInDubai hashtag#Redbond hashtag#CulturalConnections hashtag#FamilyTime hashtag#LivingAbroad hashtag#WorkLifeBalance hashtag#DubaiCommunity

The Buej Al Arab ;The Burj Al Arab, standing at 321 meters (1,053 feet), is an iconic hotel in Dubai, designed to resemble a ship's sail. Its structural system includes a reinforced concrete core with a steel exoskeleton, allowing for its distinctive shape and open atrium, the tallest in the world at 180 meters. The building is supported by 250 foundation piles, each driven 45 meters into the sand to ensure stability on the artificial island it stands on. A diagonal bracing system counteracts wind and seismic forces, while its Teflon-coated fiberglass fabric façade reduces heat absorption. The Burj Al Arab remains a marvel of modern engineering and luxury architecture.

𝐖𝐡𝐞𝐫𝐞 𝐢𝐭 𝐚𝐥𝐥 𝐛𝐞𝐠𝐮𝐧, 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐯𝐢𝐬𝐢𝐨𝐧 𝐨𝐟 𝐭𝐨𝐝𝐚𝐲'𝐬 𝐃𝐮𝐛𝐚𝐢: The Saeed Al Maktoum House in Al Shindagha, Dubai, established around 1896 as the seat of the Al Maktoum family.🎯 In 1901 ruling Sheikh Maktoum bin Hasher Al Maktoum established Dubai as a free port with no taxation on imports or exports and also gave merchants parcels of land and guarantees of protection and tolerance. That was the cornerstone on which Dubai's rapid development built up. 🎯 His son Sheikh Saeed bin Maktoum bin Hasher Al Maktoum, ruling Dubai from 1912 to 1958, continued the open and welcoming economic policies of his father. 🎯 Later during his reign Sheikh Saeed bin Maktoum ceded many of the responsibilities for driving Dubai's economic growth to his son Rashid, who became ruler of Dubai in 1958, reigning until his death in 1990. 🎯 It was this son Sheikh Rashid bin Saeed Al Maktoum, also referred to as the Father of Modern Dubai, who concluded an agreement with British Imperial Airways for flights to take place through Dubai, with flights commencing in 1937. The agreement brought welcome revenue to Dubai and was the first step to establish Dubai as an international aviation hub. 👉 When you are in Dubai, take you time to visit the Saeed Al Maktoum House and the many additional exhibition venues in Al Shindagha to admire those Sheikhs' forward looking visions that you are benefiting from today. (Photo taken by me yesterday, 26/03/2025)hashtag#dubai hashtag#business hashtag#history hashtag#vision hashtag#shindagha

The agenda opens doors to:Entrepreneurship: With initiatives to nurture startups and small businesses, entrepreneurs can thrive in an ecosystem built on innovation and support.Global Market Access: Dubai's strategic location, combined with its focus on trade and logistics, makes it a gateway for companies looking to expand their global reach.Sustainability Initiatives: Investment in renewable energy and green technologies creates avenues for businesses contributing to a sustainable future.Diverse Sectors: From technology and real estate to tourism and finance, D33 caters to diverse industries, ensuring a broad range of opportunities.For legal professionals, such as myself, D33's ambitious agenda also highlights the importance of navigating regulatory frameworks and fostering collaborations that ensure mutual growth and compliance in this dynamic business environment.Dubai is not just planning for the future, it's building it today. With the D33 vision, the emirate reinforces its reputation as a beacon of opportunity for businesses and investors worldwide.

I took my father-in-law who has traveled around the World but was still very much amazed to visit DUBAI SPICE SOUKThe Dubai Spice Souk is a bustling marketplace in the Deira district, renowned for its rich aromas and vibrant displays of spices, herbs, and dried goods. It’s not just a feast for the senses but a hub of economic activity, offering opportunities for businesses in the culinary, hospitality, and retail sectors. Entrepreneurs often source unique and high-quality ingredients, such as saffron, cinnamon, and traditional incense, to enhance their product offerings. The Souk’s approachable vendors are skilled at negotiation, making it an excellent environment for bulk purchases and cultivating supplier relationships.For business owners, the Spice Souk is more than a shopping destination—it’s a chance to tap into the heritage and authenticity that can elevate branding and customer experience.His comment- Dubai has everything to offer from luxury, brands & a perfect mix of traditional as well as modern day’s requirements. The UAE’s Economy: From Pearls to Artificial IntelligenceThe UAE was never a mere barren desert swept by the winds; rather, it was a cradle of dreams woven from the depths of the sea. Men once dived in search of pearls, those natural treasures that formed the backbone of the ancient economy. In those days, wooden boats sailed across the waters of the Gulf, carrying the hopes of sailors who braved the waves with unwavering hearts. Pearling was not merely a trade but a symbol of perseverance and patience—the very foundation of life that flourished along the shores.Then came oil, bringing with it a profound transformation in the economic landscape. The earth burst forth with its black treasures, and wealth flowed in torrents, reshaping the UAE from humble coastal settlements into dazzling oases of modernity. It was not merely a change of resources but a complete revolution in vision and planning. The wheels of development turned at an unprecedented pace, transforming sand dunes into skyscrapers and wooden dhows into world-class ports welcoming ships from every corner of the globe.Yet, the UAE did not rest on the laurels of oil wealth, for its leaders understood that finite riches could not sustain a lasting future. Thus began the leap toward a knowledge-based economy. Universities and research centers were established, technological initiatives were launched, and the UAE became a hub of innovation, attracting brilliant minds and ambitious startups. The economy was no longer just about trade and commodities but evolved into an intricate ecosystem of artificial intelligence, big data, and renewable energy, where human ingenuity intertwines seamlessly with technology.Today, the UAE stands on the threshold of the future—not only as a financial and commercial powerhouse but as a global laboratory for shaping the digital economy. From smart cities to space ventures, from artificial intelligence to blockchain technology, the UAE is redefining the contours of modern economic paradigms. This is a story written with the ink of boldness and vision, where the past was never a constraint but a launchpad toward horizons once thought unimaginable.

On March 21, 2025, the White House announced that the United Arab Emirates (UAE) committed to a 10-year, $1.4 trillion investment framework in the United States. This agreement followed a meeting between President Donald Trump and top UAE officials, including UAE National Security Adviser Sheikh Tahnoon bin Zayed Al Nahyan, earlier that week. The investment is intended to significantly expand the UAE's existing investments in the U.S. economy, focusing on areas such as AI infrastructure, semiconductors, energy, and manufacturing. One notable new project highlighted in the deal is an investment by Emirates Global Aluminium to build the first new aluminum smelter in the U.S. in 35 years, which is expected to nearly double domestic aluminum production.

This upward trajectory continued in 2024, with the market projected to hit approximately $8 billion by the end of 2025. Saudi Arabia remains a pivotal contributor, with its consulting sector growing by 14.1% in 2024 to $4.3 billion. ​Evolving Market DynamicsDespite this growth, the consulting landscape is experiencing shifts. Saudi Arabia is reassessing its expenditure on external consultants, leading to increased scrutiny and a demand for demonstrable value. This necessitates a focus on specialized expertise and tangible outcomes.​Strategic Opportunities for R Consultancy GroupThese developments present strategic opportunities for R Consultancy Group (RCG):​Specialized Expertise: RCG's deep understanding of the GCC market positions it to offer tailored solutions that address the region's unique challenges.​By focusing on delivering measurable results, RCG can meet the heightened expectations of clients seeking clear returns on their investments.​Staying abreast of market trends enables RCG to anticipate client needs and offer proactive solutions, reinforcing its role as a trusted advisor.​In summary, while the GCC consulting market continues to grow, firms must adapt to evolving client expectations. This growth was reflected in the non-oil manufacturing sector, which achieved a positive growth rate for the third consecutive quarter, reaching 17.74% during the second quarter of the 2024/2025 fiscal year, compared to the same period of the previous fiscal year, when the sector recorded a contraction rate of 11.56%. This growth was driven by the reform measures taken by the state to stimulate the national economy, foremost among them reforms aimed at increasing private sector participation in economic activity. In this regard, the government introduced customs clearance facilities for raw materials and inputs in the industrial sector, leading to increased industrial production. The sector’s contribution to GDP growth rose from 1.4- percentage points in the second quarter of the 2023/2024 fiscal year to 1.9 percentage points in this quarter, within an overall growth rate of 4.3%.Furthermore, this was also reflected in export volumes, as the state's exports of semi-manufactured and fully manufactured goods recorded significant growth during the second quarter of the 2024/2025 fiscal year. Semi-manufactured exports, which accounted for 22.4% of total merchandise exports, grew by 22.7% in the second quarter of 2024/2025 compared to the same quarter of the previous fiscal year. Fully manufactured exports, which contributed 52.1% of total merchandise exports, also grew by 8.3%. I didn’t grow up celebrating Eid – but living in Dubai has taught me just how special it really is. 🌙One of the things I’ve really come to appreciate since moving to Dubai is how the city embraces all cultures, and Eid is such a brilliant example of that.Whether you’re celebrating with family, friends, or just soaking in the atmosphere, there’s something special about this time of year. Streets lit up, gifts being exchanged, and a genuine feeling of togetherness that reminds you what matters most.As someone who didn’t grow up celebrating Eid, I’ve enjoyed learning more about it since living here. It’s not just about the public holidays or the incredible food (although that definitely helps 😄) it’s a time that brings people closer. A chance to reset, spend time with loved ones, and reflect on the year so far.For us as a family, it’s been another reminder of why we love living in Dubai. The way this city welcomes people from all walks of life and respects traditions from around the world is something quite unique.To all of you celebrating, Eid Mubarak! Wishing you and your loved ones peace, happiness and good health.And if you’re new to Dubai, I’d really recommend taking the time to experience how the city celebrates. It’s one of those cultural moments that makes living here feel all the more special.hashtag#EidMubarak hashtag#LifeInDubai hashtag#EidInDubai hashtag#ExpatsInDubai hashtag#Redbond hashtag#CulturalConnections hashtag#FamilyTime hashtag#LivingAbroad hashtag#WorkLifeBalance hashtag#DubaiCommunity

hashtag#Eid_holiday - Top Free Places to Visit in DubaiDubai offers plenty of incredible attractions that you can explore without spending a dirham on entry fees. Here are some of the best places to visit for free:1. Dubai Fountain Show (Downtown Dubai)Watch the world’s largest dancing fountain with synchronized music and lights. Timings: Every 30 minutes from 6 PM – 11 PM.2. Al Seef District (Dubai Creek)A scenic heritage area blending traditional souks with modern cafes and waterfront views.3. La Mer Beach (Jumeirah 1)A lively beachfront with stunning views, street art, and a relaxed atmosphere.4. JBR Walk & Beach (Dubai Marina)Enjoy a beautiful seaside promenade, street performances, and free beach access.5. The Pointe, Palm JumeirahWaterfront views of Atlantis The Palm and the world’s largest fountain show.7. Ras Al Khor Wildlife SanctuaryA peaceful spot to watch flamingos and other migratory birds.8. Love Lake Dubai (Al Qudra)A heart-shaped lake surrounded by nature, ideal for a peaceful escape.9. Dubai Marina WalkA 7-km scenic walkway lined with skyscrapers, cafes, and nightlife spots.10. City Walk (Downtown Dubai)A stylish urban district with free street art and futuristic architecture.14. Quranic Park (Al Khawaneej)A peaceful park with Quran-inspired gardens and exhibits.15. Located just a 90-minute drive from Dubai, this northern UAE emirate is rapidly gaining attention.🔹 Real estate transaction values leaped from AED 10M ($2.72M) in June 2017 to a massive AED 2.53 Billion ($688M) in June 2024. That's nearly a 25,000% increase!🔹 Mortgage values show a similar story, climbing from AED 15.8M in July 2017 to AED 3.47 Billion in July 2024 (~21,849% increase).According to Andrei Charapenak, CEO of Major Developers, this surge underscores soaring investor confidence and RAK's solidified position as a prime investment hub. Key drivers include strategic infrastructure projects, hospitality investments, and a growing appetite for luxury, sustainable, and lifestyle-integrated properties.It's clear RAK's strategic vision is paying off, attracting significant investment and reshaping its economic landscape.

The Buej Al Arab ;The Burj Al Arab, standing at 321 meters (1,053 feet), is an iconic hotel in Dubai, designed to resemble a ship's sail. Its structural system includes a reinforced concrete core with a steel exoskeleton, allowing for its distinctive shape and open atrium, the tallest in the world at 180 meters. The building is supported by 250 foundation piles, each driven 45 meters into the sand to ensure stability on the artificial island it stands on. A diagonal bracing system counteracts wind and seismic forces, while its Teflon-coated fiberglass fabric façade reduces heat absorption. The Burj Al Arab remains a marvel of modern engineering and luxury architecture.

𝐖𝐡𝐞𝐫𝐞 𝐢𝐭 𝐚𝐥𝐥 𝐛𝐞𝐠𝐮𝐧, 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐯𝐢𝐬𝐢𝐨𝐧 𝐨𝐟 𝐭𝐨𝐝𝐚𝐲'𝐬 𝐃𝐮𝐛𝐚𝐢: The Saeed Al Maktoum House in Al Shindagha, Dubai, established around 1896 as the seat of the Al Maktoum family.🎯 In 1901 ruling Sheikh Maktoum bin Hasher Al Maktoum established Dubai as a free port with no taxation on imports or exports and also gave merchants parcels of land and guarantees of protection and tolerance. That was the cornerstone on which Dubai's rapid development built up. 🎯 His son Sheikh Saeed bin Maktoum bin Hasher Al Maktoum, ruling Dubai from 1912 to 1958, continued the open and welcoming economic policies of his father. 🎯 Later during his reign Sheikh Saeed bin Maktoum ceded many of the responsibilities for driving Dubai's economic growth to his son Rashid, who became ruler of Dubai in 1958, reigning until his death in 1990. 🎯 It was this son Sheikh Rashid bin Saeed Al Maktoum, also referred to as the Father of Modern Dubai, who concluded an agreement with British Imperial Airways for flights to take place through Dubai, with flights commencing in 1937. The agreement brought welcome revenue to Dubai and was the first step to establish Dubai as an international aviation hub. 👉 When you are in Dubai, take you time to visit the Saeed Al Maktoum House and the many additional exhibition venues in Al Shindagha to admire those Sheikhs' forward looking visions that you are benefiting from today. (Photo taken by me yesterday, 26/03/2025)hashtag#dubai hashtag#business hashtag#history hashtag#vision hashtag#shindagha

Shaping the Future: Dubai's D33 VisionDubai's D33 Economic Agenda was launched on January 4, 2023 by His Highness Sheikh Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum, Vice President and Prime Minister of the UAE and Ruler of Dubai Dubai has always been synonymous with ambition, innovation, and a forward-thinking mindset. It’s not just a feast for the senses but a hub of economic activity, offering opportunities for businesses in the culinary, hospitality, and retail sectors. Entrepreneurs often source unique and high-quality ingredients, such as saffron, cinnamon, and traditional incense, to enhance their product offerings. The Souk’s approachable vendors are skilled at negotiation, making it an excellent environment for bulk purchases and cultivating supplier relationships.For business owners, the Spice Souk is more than a shopping destination—it’s a chance to tap into the heritage and authenticity that can elevate branding and customer experience.His comment- Dubai has everything to offer from luxury, brands & a perfect mix of traditional as well as modern day’s requirements. The UAE’s Economy: From Pearls to Artificial IntelligenceThe UAE was never a mere barren desert swept by the winds; rather, it was a cradle of dreams woven from the depths of the sea. Men once dived in search of pearls, those natural treasures that formed the backbone of the ancient economy. In those days, wooden boats sailed across the waters of the Gulf, carrying the hopes of sailors who braved the waves with unwavering hearts. Pearling was not merely a trade but a symbol of perseverance and patience—the very foundation of life that flourished along the shores.Then came oil, bringing with it a profound transformation in the economic landscape. The earth burst forth with its black treasures, and wealth flowed in torrents, reshaping the UAE from humble coastal settlements into dazzling oases of modernity. It was not merely a change of resources but a complete revolution in vision and planning. The wheels of development turned at an unprecedented pace, transforming sand dunes into skyscrapers and wooden dhows into world-class ports welcoming ships from every corner of the globe.Yet, the UAE did not rest on the laurels of oil wealth, for its leaders understood that finite riches could not sustain a lasting future. Thus began the leap toward a knowledge-based economy. Universities and research centers were established, technological initiatives were launched, and the UAE became a hub of innovation, attracting brilliant minds and ambitious startups. The economy was no longer just about trade and commodities but evolved into an intricate ecosystem of artificial intelligence, big data, and renewable energy, where human ingenuity intertwines seamlessly with technology.Today, the UAE stands on the threshold of the future—not only as a financial and commercial powerhouse but as a global laboratory for shaping the digital economy. From smart cities to space ventures, from artificial intelligence to blockchain technology, the UAE is redefining the contours of modern economic paradigms. This is a story written with the ink of boldness and vision, where the past was never a constraint but a launchpad toward horizons once thought unimaginable.

On March 21, 2025, the White House announced that the United Arab Emirates (UAE) committed to a 10-year, $1.4 trillion investment framework in the United States. This agreement followed a meeting between President Donald Trump and top UAE officials, including UAE National Security Adviser Sheikh Tahnoon bin Zayed Al Nahyan, earlier that week. The investment is intended to significantly expand the UAE's existing investments in the U.S. economy, focusing on areas such as AI infrastructure, semiconductors, energy, and manufacturing. One notable new project highlighted in the deal is an investment by Emirates Global Aluminium to build the first new aluminum smelter in the U.S. in 35 years, which is expected to nearly double domestic aluminum production.
